ID: CQGUCT4_00
From: Hagop Ghazarian <Hagop.Ghazarian@chalhoub.com>
To: Dee Deu <dee.deu@chalhoub.com>
CC: Kamran Abbasi <Kamran.Abbasi@chalhoub.com>; Joe Hobeika <Joe.Hobeika@chalhoub.com>
BCC: 
Date: 2025-04-29 10:26
Subject: Final Insurance Deck for Review - Cyber Insurance
--------------------------------------------------
Dear Dee,

I hope this message finds you well.

The final version of the insurance deck is now complete and ready for your review. I have attached all relevant documentation, including a summary presentation to facilitate a clear understanding of the key points.

Please note that Zurich will be partnering with Beazley for a 50% securitization by each insurer, with the policy being issued and fully managed through Beazley (UK-based). Orient is securitized by Lloyd’s, with policy issuance and management handled by Orient Takaful.

All relevant documents are included for your convenience. I recommend scheduling a call, including Joe and Kamran, to align on the details and agree on a scoring metric. This will ensure full alignment as we move forward.

Please feel free to reach out should you require any further information or clarification.

I look forward to your thoughts and to receiving a proposed time for the call.

Best regards,
Hagop

ID: CQGUCT4_02
From: Hagop Ghazarian <Hagop.Ghazarian@chalhoub.com>
To: Dee Deu <dee.deu@chalhoub.com>
CC: Kamran Abbasi <Kamran.Abbasi@chalhoub.com>; Joe Hobeika <Joe.Hobeika@chalhoub.com>
BCC: 
Date: 2025-05-01 10:35
Subject: RE: Final Insurance Deck for Review - Cyber Insurance
--------------------------------------------------
Hi Dee,


Thank you for your prompt reply.

Just to manage expectations, please note that for any legal check requests that include insurance-related elements, Legal will route them to me for review.

Also, unlike service contracts, insurance policy wordings are standardized across the industry. As a result, no direct changes can be made to the policy wording, as insurers rely on this standardization to price the risk reliably and to minimize unpredictability.

However, we can include certain technical requirements as special conditions above and beyond the general wording—think of it as an addendum sheet. However, please note that the core wording itself cannot be modified.

ID: CQGUCT4_03
From: Dee Deu <dee.deu@chalhoub.com>
To: Hagop Ghazarian <Hagop.Ghazarian@chalhoub.com>
CC: Kamran Abbasi <Kamran.Abbasi@chalhoub.com>; Joe Hobeika <Joe.Hobeika@chalhoub.com>
BCC: 
Date: 2025-05-14 14:37
Subject: RE: Final Insurance Deck for Review - Cyber Insurance
--------------------------------------------------
Dear Hagop,

 

Thank you for sharing the final documentation and summary presentation.

 

We have reviewed all materials in detail and can confirm that we have no further technical concerns at this stage. From our side, the proposals are clear, and it is now a matter of how you would like to proceed.

 

That said, based on our technical assessment, the Beazley option meets more of our critical requirements—particularly in areas related to incident response readiness, coverage structure, and preventive service offerings.

 

I have attached the proposed scoring matrix for your reference; please feel free to suggest any amendments and add your inputs.

 

Happy to join a call with Joe and Kamran to align on the evaluation approach and scoring, and ensure we move forward with full clarity.

 

Please feel free to suggest a time that works best.

 

Kind Regards

 

Dee

ID: CQGUCT4_04
From: Hagop Ghazarian <Hagop.Ghazarian@chalhoub.com>
To: Dee Deu <dee.deu@chalhoub.com>
CC: Kamran Abbasi <Kamran.Abbasi@chalhoub.com>; Joe Hobeika <Joe.Hobeika@chalhoub.com>
BCC: 
Date: 2025-05-21 12:23
Subject: Re: Final Insurance Deck for Review - Cyber Insurance
--------------------------------------------------
Dear Dee,

Thank you for providing your feedback and for reviewing the documentation.

I would like to clarify that CFC is not an independent insurer but the incident response service provider for Orient Takaful. As such, the correct comparison is between Orient Takaful via Nasco and Beazley via Marsh.

That being said, I agree that the Beazley proposal is the stronger option overall. In terms of coverage, both proposals are quite similar; however, Beazley has a few key advantages over the Orient proposal:


*	
	Event Limitation: Orient's proposal includes an event limitation of 28 days, effectively resetting the policy every 28 days. This means a single incident could be considered as multiple claims, each with a separate USD 250k deductible, which is a significant downside.

metadata.doc_id: CQGUCT4 - final insurance deck for review - cyber insurance\Conversation.txt
metadata.doc_path: C:\Users\ASUS\Desktop\Outlook\CQGUCT4 - final insurance deck for review - cyber insurance\Conversation.txt

chunks.text:
*	
	Event Limitation: Orient's proposal includes an event limitation of 28 days, effectively resetting the policy every 28 days. This means a single incident could be considered as multiple claims, each with a separate USD 250k deductible, which is a significant downside.

*	
	Marsh's CyberWall Wording: Beazley will be using Marsh's CyberWall wording which is cleaner with less ambiguity than that of the general wording used by Orient.
	
	
*	
	Biometric Data Privacy Exclusion: Beazley does not have a biometric privacy exclusion, unlike Orient, which excludes coverage for breach of privacy claims arising from the collection, use, or handling of biometric data, such as fingerprints or facial scans.


Both CFC and Beazley’s in-house teams are excellent when it comes to incident response. However, Beazley has a slight edge as they are the leading provider of cyber insurance globally, insuring approximately 7% of the worldwide. Also, Beazley was the first insurer to introduce first-party cyber coverage and has extensive experience in the field. Additionally, Beazley’s add-on services are more adaptable to the cyber-readiness needs of the group.

CFC also offers excellent services with a more tech-driven approach, including real-time cyber news updates, dark web monitoring, etc. However, the value of these services will depend on how relevant they are to our specific needs based on our profile.

metadata.doc_id: CQGUCT4 - final insurance deck for review - cyber insurance\Conversation.txt
metadata.doc_path: C:\Users\ASUS\Desktop\Outlook\CQGUCT4 - final insurance deck for review - cyber insurance\Conversation.txt

chunks.text:
CFC also offers excellent services with a more tech-driven approach, including real-time cyber news updates, dark web monitoring, etc. However, the value of these services will depend on how relevant they are to our specific needs based on our profile.

In terms of securitization, both options are strong. The Orient policy is fully reinsured with Lloyd’s, while Beazley’s holds 50% directly, with the remaining 50% reinsured to Zurich (A+ rated) on follower basis.

Overall, Beazley’s structure is leaner and potentially more efficient, with the chain being: 


Chalhoub -> Marsh -> Beazley           vs
Chalhoub -> Nasco -> Orient -> Lloyd’s

As for feedback on the brokers, Marsh demonstrated significantly higher technical expertise than Nasco both in person and which also showed with their proposals. Their proposals were cleaner, more complete, and required fewer amendments, while Nasco’s proposals had  subjectivities and always required additional information or changes to make them viable.

Finally, in terms of structuring the policy, I would recommend a minimum two-year agreement with predefined renewal conditions. As you have seen, the cyber insurance placement process is very intrusive and requires considerable information to be share for proper underwriting. A two-year term would allow for a reassessment of the group’s risk profile as the rollouts you have planned progress.

Regarding the meeting, I would appreciate it if you could suggest a suitable timing, including Kamran and Joe. Once we align during the meeting, we can update the scorecard together.

Best Regards,
Hagop

Sent: Tuesday, 29 April 2025 10:26 AM
To: Dee Deu <dee.deu@chalhoub.com>
Cc: Kamran Abbasi <Kamran.Abbasi@chalhoub.com>; Joe Hobeika <Joe.Hobeika@chalhoub.com>
Subject: Final Insurance Deck for Review - Cyber Insurance

 

Dear Dee,

 

I hope this message finds you well.

 

The final version of the insurance deck is now complete and ready for your review. I have attached all relevant documentation, including a summary presentation to facilitate a clear understanding of the key points.

 

Please note that Zurich will be partnering with Beazley for a 50% securitization by each insurer, with the policy being issued and fully managed through Beazley (UK-based). Orient is securitized by Lloyd’s, with policy issuance and management handled by Orient Takaful.

From: Hagop Ghazarian <Hagop.Ghazarian@chalhoub.com> 
Sent: 21 May 2025 12:23 PM
To: Dee Deu <dee.deu@chalhoub.com>
Cc: Kamran Abbasi <Kamran.Abbasi@chalhoub.com>; Joe Hobeika <Joe.Hobeika@chalhoub.com>
Subject: Re: Final Insurance Deck for Review - Cyber Insurance

 

Dear Dee,

 

Thank you for providing your feedback and for reviewing the documentation.

 

I would like to clarify that CFC is not an independent insurer but the incident response service provider for Orient Takaful. As such, the correct comparison is between Orient Takaful via Nasco and Beazley via Marsh.

metadata.doc_id: CQGUCT4 - final insurance deck for review - cyber insurance\Conversation.txt
metadata.doc_path: C:\Users\ASUS\Desktop\Outlook\CQGUCT4 - final insurance deck for review - cyber insurance\Conversation.txt

chunks.text:
I would like to clarify that CFC is not an independent insurer but the incident response service provider for Orient Takaful. As such, the correct comparison is between Orient Takaful via Nasco and Beazley via Marsh.

 

That being said, I agree that the Beazley proposal is the stronger option overall. In terms of coverage, both proposals are quite similar; however, Beazley has a few key advantages over the Orient proposal:

 

*	Event Limitation: Orient's proposal includes an event limitation of 28 days, effectively resetting the policy every 28 days. This means a single incident could be considered as multiple claims, each with a separate USD 250k deductible, which is a significant downside.

 

*	Marsh's CyberWall Wording: Beazley will be using Marsh's CyberWall wording which is cleaner with less ambiguity than that of the general wording used by Orient.

 

*	Biometric Data Privacy Exclusion: Beazley does not have a biometric privacy exclusion, unlike Orient, which excludes coverage for breach of privacy claims arising from the collection, use, or handling of biometric data, such as fingerprints or facial scans.

 

Both CFC and Beazley’s in-house teams are excellent when it comes to incident response. However, Beazley has a slight edge as they are the leading provider of cyber insurance globally, insuring approximately 7% of the worldwide. Also, Beazley was the first insurer to introduce first-party cyber coverage and has extensive experience in the field. Additionally, Beazley’s add-on services are more adaptable to the cyber-readiness needs of the group.

metadata.doc_id: CQGUCT4 - final insurance deck for review - cyber insurance\Conversation.txt
metadata.doc_path: C:\Users\ASUS\Desktop\Outlook\CQGUCT4 - final insurance deck for review - cyber insurance\Conversation.txt

chunks.text:
Both CFC and Beazley’s in-house teams are excellent when it comes to incident response. However, Beazley has a slight edge as they are the leading provider of cyber insurance globally, insuring approximately 7% of the worldwide. Also, Beazley was the first insurer to introduce first-party cyber coverage and has extensive experience in the field. Additionally, Beazley’s add-on services are more adaptable to the cyber-readiness needs of the group.

 

CFC also offers excellent services with a more tech-driven approach, including real-time cyber news updates, dark web monitoring, etc. However, the value of these services will depend on how relevant they are to our specific needs based on our profile.

 

In terms of securitization, both options are strong. The Orient policy is fully reinsured with Lloyd’s, while Beazley’s holds 50% directly, with the remaining 50% reinsured to Zurich (A+ rated) on follower basis.

 

Overall, Beazley’s structure is leaner and potentially more efficient, with the chain being: 

Chalhoub -> Marsh -> Beazley           vs

Chalhoub -> Nasco -> Orient -> Lloyd’s

 

As for feedback on the brokers, Marsh demonstrated significantly higher technical expertise than Nasco both in person and which also showed with their proposals. Their proposals were cleaner, more complete, and required fewer amendments, while Nasco’s proposals had  subjectivities and always required additional information or changes to make them viable.

metadata.doc_id: CQGUCT4 - final insurance deck for review - cyber insurance\Conversation.txt
metadata.doc_path: C:\Users\ASUS\Desktop\Outlook\CQGUCT4 - final insurance deck for review - cyber insurance\Conversation.txt

chunks.text:
As for feedback on the brokers, Marsh demonstrated significantly higher technical expertise than Nasco both in person and which also showed with their proposals. Their proposals were cleaner, more complete, and required fewer amendments, while Nasco’s proposals had  subjectivities and always required additional information or changes to make them viable.

 

Finally, in terms of structuring the policy, I would recommend a minimum two-year agreement with predefined renewal conditions. As you have seen, the cyber insurance placement process is very intrusive and requires considerable information to be share for proper underwriting. A two-year term would allow for a reassessment of the group’s risk profile as the rollouts you have planned progress.

 

Regarding the meeting, I would appreciate it if you could suggest a suitable timing, including Kamran and Joe. Once we align during the meeting, we can update the scorecard together.

 

Best Regards,

Hagop

 

HAGOP GHAZARIAN

From: Dee Deu <dee.deu@chalhoub.com <mailto:dee.deu@chalhoub.com> >
Sent: Wednesday, May 14, 2025 2:37 PM
To: Hagop Ghazarian <Hagop.Ghazarian@chalhoub.com <mailto:Hagop.Ghazarian@chalhoub.com> >
Cc: Kamran Abbasi <Kamran.Abbasi@chalhoub.com <mailto:Kamran.Abbasi@chalhoub.com> >; Joe Hobeika <Joe.Hobeika@chalhoub.com <mailto:Joe.Hobeika@chalhoub.com> >
Subject: RE: Final Insurance Deck for Review - Cyber Insurance 

 

Dear Hagop,

 

Thank you for sharing the final documentation and summary presentation.

 

We have reviewed all materials in detail and can confirm that we have no further technical concerns at this stage. From our side, the proposals are clear, and it is now a matter of how you would like to proceed.

 

That said, based on our technical assessment, the Beazley option meets more of our critical requirements—particularly in areas related to incident response readiness, coverage structure, and preventive service offerings.

 

I have attached the proposed scoring matrix for your reference; please feel free to suggest any amendments and add your inputs.

 

Happy to join a call with Joe and Kamran to align on the evaluation approach and scoring, and ensure we move forward with full clarity.

 

Please feel free to suggest a time that works best.

 

Kind Regards

 

Dee

 

DEE DEU

DIRECTOR ‑ INFORMATION SECURITY

M.C.T. FZE

DUBAI

‑
